title: Engage Professional Insurance Claim Officers – Motorists Told
text:
16:09 CET Engage Professional Insurance Claim Officers – Motorists Told By Daily Guide 
Gabriel Glover (middle) poses with participants in Takoradi 
Chief Executive Officer (CEO) of the Ghana National Bureau of ECOWAS Brown Card Insurance Scheme Gabriel Glover has asked motorists to engage professional insurance claim officers to guarantee compensation anytime they are involved in accidents. 
According to him, the activities of fake insurance claim officers have led to high accident claims that negatively affects the industry. 
Mr. Glover gave the warning at a day's capacity-building workshop at Takoradi on the ECOWAS Brown Card Insurance Schemes. 
He bemoaned the lack of knowledge on the ECOWAS Brown Card Scheme among all stakeholders and the general public at large. 
Mr Glover said stakeholders take actions which lead to the curtailment of free movement of goods and persons, the arrest and detention of foreign motorists involved in motor accidents, circulation of fake Brown Cards and the delay in payment of compensation to victims. 
Fake Brown Cards The CEO expressed displeasure about the existence of fake Brown Cards, which also defeat the purpose of the Scheme, stating that victims of accidents caused by holders of fake Brown Cards cannot be compensated. 
'This development makes the ECOWAS Brown Card Insurance Scheme lose huge amounts of income hence its lack of ability to meet claims in the sub-region,' he said. 
In view of this, Mr. Glover said a new secure ECOWAS Brown Card was adopted in Coutonou, Benin on October 12, 2011 during the 28 th Ordinary Session of the Council of Bureaux of the ECOWAS Brown Card Insurance Scheme. 
He said the new Brown Card is a single leaflet format with security features that cannot be seen by the unaided eye, adding 'this is an improved certificate which is expected to curb the use of fake Brown Cards in our community.' 
The Workshop The workshop, which forms part of series of educational campaigns being organised by the Ghana National Bureau of the ECOWAS Brown Card Insurance Scheme, was attended by representatives of various insurance companies. 
It was aimed at sensitising stakeholders and member companies across the country on the procedures and operations of the Brown Card Insurance Scheme. 
They were also educated on the legal Texts and Harmonized Convention for Motor Victims' Compensation as well as claims calculation for both injury and deceased. 
By Cephas Larbi
